title: 109_hr117
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act of 2005" and includes a deduction for higher education expenses. The "Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act of 2005" includes an increase in the dollar limitation for qualified tuition and related expenses for the first 2 years of postsecondary education. The limit is set at $10,000 for each eligible student, up to a maximum of $15,000. The "Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act of 2005" raises the limit for qualified tuition and related expenses for the first 2 years of postsecondary education to $10,000 per eligible student, with a maximum of $15,000. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is $10,000, except for specific cases where it is reduced to $5,000 or zero. The deduction is limited to 4 taxable years for each eligible student. The term 'eligible student' is defined in section 25A(b)(3). Section 222 of the Code is amended by removing subsection (e). Adjusted gross income calculations for certain benefits are to be determined without considering section 222. Section 24(b)(1), 151(d)(3), 165(h)(2)(A)(ii), 213(a), and 1400C(b)(2) of the Code are all amended by inserting "222," before "911" and adjusting gross income calculations without considering section 222. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2004 for education in academic periods beginning after that date. SEC. 3. EDUCATION TAX CREDIT FAIRNESS. Increase in AGI Limits for the Hope credit under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amount taken into account is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The adjusted gross income limits for the Lifetime Learning Credit are based on the taxpayer's income for the taxable year, with reductions for amounts exceeding certain thresholds. The adjusted gross income limits for the Lifetime Learning Credit are based on the taxpayer's income for the taxable year, with reductions for amounts exceeding certain thresholds. The modified adjusted gross income is calculated by adding any excluded amounts from gross income under specific sections. The income limits for the Hope credit and Lifetime Learning credit are adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The income limits for the Hope credit and Lifetime Learning credit are adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. $80,000 amounts in subsection (d)(2)(B)(i)(II) shall be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the taxable year. Rounding rules apply if the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $1,000. Coordination with other higher education benefits is also addressed in the Code. The Code adjusts income limits for education credits annually based on cost-of-living adjustments. Section 25A(g) is amended to renumber paragraphs and apply changes to expenses paid after December 31, 2004. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct an annual study to analyze the impact of Federal income tax incentives on higher education tuition rates. The results will be reported to Congress annually. The House of Representatives believes the maximum Pell Grant should be increased to $4,700 to cover a significant portion of college expenses.
